pr_title: Update: convert game parser to use xml-reader and map-data (StAX based parser)

timeline.message:
Update: convert game parser to use xml-reader and map-data (StAX based parser)

- Changes GameParser over to use xml-reader & map-data
 This conversion allows for more flexibility when parsing as we can more
 easily get the same different from different locations.

- Game parsing no longer requires or uses a DTD
 This gives us flexibility going forward if change tags, an old or new map
 that does not conform to such a standard would not get a DTD failure
 and we can help migrate the compatibility in code. DTD is still
 useful for validation and we should see about building a map validation
 tool that would use it.

- GameParsing becomes simpler, it now assembles a GameData instead of
 parsing XML. The details of XML parsing are removed and things like
 checking for child nodes is removed and we get native java types
 that are already converted to for example integers or booleans.

timeline.message:
Install a newer version of Java in Travis

Getting an odd parse error within CDATA of an XML.
The java version on travis is a bit dated, trying
a newer JDK to resolve.

Update: convert game parser to use xml-reader and map-data (StAX based parser)

- Changes GameParser over to use xml-reader & map-data
 This conversion allows for more flexibility when parsing as we can more
 easily get the same different from different locations.

- Game parsing no longer requires or uses a DTD
 This gives us flexibility going forward if change tags, an old or new map
 that does not conform to such a standard would not get a DTD failure
 and we can help migrate the compatibility in code. DTD is still
 useful for validation and we should see about building a map validation
 tool that would use it.

- GameParsing becomes simpler, it now assembles a GameData instead of
 parsing XML. The details of XML parsing are removed and things like
 checking for child nodes is removed and we get native java types
 that are already converted to for example integers or booleans.

Keep parse exceptions at severe level.

While this could create noise with error reports, knowing the frequency
and why players hit parse exceptions can be useful. For example
otherwise we would have not known about the continued prevelance
of 'attatchment' parse errors.

timeline.bodyText: I wonder where this check comes from. If the list is empty the for loop shouldn't iterate a single time and getRelationShipTracker doesn't look like it would throw an exception
timeline.author: RoiEXLab
